instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP20V_USBC: What is PP20V_USBC? 20 volt power rail that comes directly from the charger.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> cycling on/off (5.18v/0v)
threads.message:
Hello

Have this board that caming in with no power. 5.18v on <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL>. <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, UB300, UB400 all cycle when power is applied to their port. <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> is steady at 5.18v. Found corrosion on by and around <RESISTOR>R3108</RESISTOR>. Cleaned up the corrosion, confirmed the resistors were good. Also replaced <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> (2 times to confirm replacement chip wasn't DOA). This didn't fix.

Replaced all 4 USBC port chips with the same issue. 
Started ohm'ing around and found 1.8ohms on LA640. Removed both LA640 and 650, still reading 1.8 on on LA640(2). Is 1.8 too low or is the GPU shorted?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> cycling on/off (5.18v/0v)
threads.message:
I don't exactly know the value on GPU CORE.
1.8 ohm could be normal; should be good if someone confirm in similar board.

Post diode mode (red probe to ground) on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and all other big coils.
Don't forget to check L6900 too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> cycling on/off (5.18v/0v)
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> cycling on/off (5.18v/0v)
threads.message:
Remove F7000 and check if get some voltage at its pad 1.
Also post exact <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage.
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> cycling on/off (5.18v/0v)
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.41 and stable when power on <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>. Pulsing down to 0.4 when powered by <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>.

Remove F7000 and 7001. Getting 0.05 on both the steady usbc port and the pulsing one. 

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - getting steady 3.4 with steady usbc port and pulsing on pulsing one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> cycling on/off (5.18v/0v)
threads.message:
You must have some problem on USB-C ports.
All ports should have the same behaviour; even if machine not working.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> cycling on/off (5.18v/0v)
threads.message:
you were right. Found a missing resistor that's not called out in the schematic or board view. It appears the board view for this board isn't correct. It looks like its the board view for <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. To the left of <RESISTOR>R3109</RESISTOR> is a 100Kohm resistor. So when i saw this resistor, i assumed it was taking the place of <RESISTOR>R3109</RESISTOR> (<RESISTOR>R3109</RESISTOR> was actually missing). Anyway, went ahead and installed the 1Mohm resistor for <RESISTOR>R3109</RESISTOR> and that did the trick. 

So, this also means that 1.8ohm resistance reading on LA640 and 650 are the expected reading. 

Anyway, thanks for the assist.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> cycling on/off (5.18v/0v)
threads.message:
Glad to hear you've solved it.
If you still have access on this board, can you please post diode mode on all big coils?
This will help a lot other people.
BTW, post ohm scale value for readings lower than 010 in diode mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> cycling on/off (5.18v/0v)
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> cycling on/off (5.18v/0v)
threads.message: Many thanks, this is very usefull information...
